description: Follow these steps to apply for a .gov.uk domain name.

details.body:
1: Check you can apply for a .gov.uk domain name

You must check:

  • your organisation is eligible for a .gov.uk domain name
  • there’s a registrant in place who will manage the domain
  • the proposed domain name meets the choose your .gov.uk domain name rules
  • you have the appropriate written permission from your organisation

2: Find a .gov.uk Approved Registrar to submit your application 

Once you have confirmed you can apply, you must choose a .gov.uk Approved Registrar who will make the application for you. 

The .gov.uk Registrar will ask you for:

  • the name of the person registering the domain (registrant)
  • your organisation 
  • your existing contact details, so we can help identify you work in the public sector
  • your role and role-based email you want published in the online registry

If you are applying from a central government organisation or arm’s length body you will also be asked to provide:

  • proof you have permission to apply for a .gov.uk domain name 
  • proof you have an exemption from using the GOV.UK website 

The cost of buying a domain will depend on the supplier and the services you are buying. Registrars are free to set their own prices for providing the registration and DNS services of .gov.uk domains, but must itemise separately and explicitly for services they provide. See pricing of .gov.uk domains for more information.

3: Wait for a decision from the Domains Team

The Domains Team will review your .gov.uk domain name application.

We will approve or reject your application within 5 working days of receiving a completed application. If your application is missing details or needs clarification, this may take longer. 

The Domains Team may refer any .gov.uk domain name application to the Naming and Approvals Committee for a final decision.

4: Get your domain set up and start using it or appeal a decision

If your domain name is approved your .gov.uk Approved Registrar will set up it for you so you can start using it. Follow guidance on getting started with your .gov.uk domain name.

You can appeal rejected .gov.uk domain name application decisions in certain circumstances.

change_history.note: Updated all steps as the Get approval to use a .gov.uk domain name service has launched and the application process has changed.
Updates to the pricing to align with other pages
Changed 'Domain Name Administrator' to 'Registrant' to align with standard industry terminology.
Clarified that it is still acceptable to use a registrar's email address when you apply for a domain, if you organisation does not have a role-based email at the time of application.
Clarified introduction to make it clear the domain name administrator starts the application process by finding a registrar. Also updated the pricing of .gov.uk domains
The Domain Management team has now moved to the Central Digital and Data Office. This update removes any references to the Government Digital Service (GDS).
Adding in information about baseline costs of an application

contents.text: If your organisation is eligible for a .gov.uk domain name, you must identify a registrant who is going to be responsible for the domain and then choose a .gov.uk Approved Registrar.

contents.text: Registrants must follow the Cabinet Office guidelines once their .gov.uk domain is live, or Cabinet Office will withdraw it. For example, registrants must keep contact details up to date.

contents: @{href=/guidance/use-your-govuk-domain-name; text=Get started with your .gov.uk domain name}

contents.text: Registrants or their Technical Points of Contact can make changes to a .gov.uk domain name.

contents: @{href=/guidance/make-changes-to-your-govuk-domain-name; text=Modify or transfer your domain name}

contents.text: If your organisation no longer needs a domain name, you must take steps to protect it.
